    Targeting Lysosomal Degradation Pathways: New Strategies and Techniques for Drug Discovery

    • Junping Pei
      Junping Pei

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    A series of tools for targeted protein degradation are inspiring scientists to develop new drugs with advantages over traditional small-molecule drugs. Among these tools, proteolysis-targeting chimeras (PROTACs) are most representative of the technology based on proteasomes. However, the proteasome has little degradation effect on certain macromolecular proteins or aggregates, extracellular proteins, and organelles, which limits the application of PROTACs. Additionally, lysosomes play an important role in protein degradation. Therefore, lysosome-induced protein degradation drugs can directly regulate protein levels in vivo, achieve the goal of treating diseases, and provide new strategies for drug discovery. Lysosome-based degradation technology has the potential for clinical translation. In this review, strategies targeting lysosomal pathways and lysosome-based degradation techniques are summarized. In addition, lysosome-based degrading drugs are described, and the advantages and challenges are listed. Our efforts will certainly promote the design, discovery, and clinical application of drugs associated with this technology.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Lysosomes are ubiquitous organelles that can degrade proteins, nucleic acids, polysaccharides, and other biomaterials.(1) Extracellular substances and cytoplasmic membrane proteins (such as receptors or channels) can enter the cell through endocytosis and are then degraded in the lysosome, which contribute to plasma membrane repair, the immune response, bone resorption, and pathogen elimination in stores. Intracellular damaged proteins or organelles are wrapped by autophagosomes in autophagy. Then, autophagosomes fuse with lysosomes to form autolysosomes, which can degrade these cargoes and release the resulting short products back into the cytosol for reuse (Figure 1).(2â4) The lysosomal membrane contains proteins that are involved in the import and export of substances to the lysosome.(5) Lysosomal exocytosis not only is critical for the secretion of lysosomal content but also contributes to plasma membrane repair, the immune response, bone resorption, and pathogen elimination.(6,7) The regulation of intracellular substance levels through lysosomes is of great significance for maintaining the normal metabolic activities of cells and defending against microbial infections.(8) The lysosomal system and proteasome pathway are the two most significant degradation pathways in cells.(9) Two pathways not only interact with each other through a certain mechanism to achieve compensatory or synergistic outcomes but also play an independent role to ensure the specificity of the degradation of biomaterials in cells.(10) In particular, the lysosomal pathway plays an important role in regulating intracellular and extracellular protein homeostasis.
    Many diseases are caused by the mutation or accumulation of specific proteins. The specific degradation of these pathogenic proteins can fundamentally intervene in or treat diseases, which has important scientific and clinical value and is revolutionizing the biomedical field.(11) In recent years, scientists have been inspired by the natural regulation of protein levels, which is the normal physiological process of protein metabolism in organismal cells.(12â14) This result has led to the rapid emergence of protein-silencing tools, such as proteolysis-targeting chimeras (PROTACs)(15â17) at the posttranslational level, biological tools (e.g., RNAi(18) and CRISPR(19)), and other methods (e.g., Trim-Away,(20) dTAGs,(21,22) and SNIPERs(23)). Among these tools, PROTAC is the most potent method for drug discovery. Currently, three PROTAC molecules (ARV-110 in NCT03888612, ARV471 in NCT04072952, and CC-94676) have entered clinical trials. Some clinical trial data revealed that ARV110 has good oral bioavailability, a high safety profile, and adequate tolerance for use in cancer treatment. However, PROTACs can only degrade certain intracellular proteins. Lysosomes can effectively remove certain large proteins or aggregates, damaged or excess organelles and extracellular proteins (Figure 2),(1,24,25) that are closely related to cancer,(26) autoimmune disorders,(27) and/or aging-related diseases.(28) Therefore, the strategy of lysosome-based selective degradation of biomaterials has the potential to improve human health. The future development and clinical transformation of lysosome-based degraders will lead to exciting and important developments in the treatment of diseases through protein degradation.
    Therefore, lysosome-based degradation of disease-related proteins can greatly enrich the techniques for inducing protein degradation and is complementary to proteasomal degradation.(29) Autophagy agonists cannot specifically degrade abnormal proteins through lysosomes. Therefore, the development of a technique to specifically degrade disease-related proteins through lysosomes without affecting normal metabolized proteins, which represents a new strategy for the discovery of innovative drugs, is of great practical value. Here, we review the main ways to degrade biomaterials, including biological molecules and diseased organelles through lysosomes and the recent emergence of new techniques associated with this approach. Finally, we outline the achievements and challenges associated with targeted lysosomal degradation. In summary, new strategies for targeting protein and organelle degradation through the lysosomal pathway provide new ideas for drug discovery.

    Degradation of Proteins and Organelles through the Lysosomal Pathway

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The balance of intracellular substances, the maintenance of cell homeostasis, and the normal cellular physiological functions of the body are inseparable from the lysosomal degradation pathway and proteasome system. These two pathways are independent but exhibit cross talk.(30â34) On the one hand, the ubiquitinâproteasome system mainly degrades soluble,(35) short-lived, and monomeric misfolded proteins, while the lysosomal system mainly degrades long-lived proteins, protein aggregates, and damaged organelles.(36) Both autophagy and ubiquitinâproteasome systems can degrade substrates through ubiquitination. On the other hand, the two pathways can synergistically degrade the same substrate in the cell. Additionally, because interference by one pathway affects the activity of the other, these pathways are interdependent.(37â39) Therefore, research on lysosomal degradation in vivo broadens the understanding of the mechanism underlying cell degradation-related diseases. Protein degradation through lysosomal pathways has greatly expanded the range of molecules known to act as substrates, providing a new strategy for targeting many traditionally nontargeted proteins, such as backbone proteins and transcription factors, bacteria, and viruses. On the basis of lysosome-targeted receptors, endocytosis, and autophagy, more novel strategies can be developed to selectively reduce the degradation of biological materials in vivo through the lysosomal system.
    The transport of proteins to lysosomes can be hijacked by lysosome-targeting receptors (LTRs). The formation of lysosomes is a complex process involving multiple pathways, and different types of cells and even the same type of cell may adopt different pathways. Lysosomal hydrolases are synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum and enter the lysosome in different ways.(5,24,40) Currently, two main approaches are used: in one mechanism, most hydrolytic enzymes are modified with mannose 6-phosphate receptor (M6PR) residues, which are recognized by the Golgi apparatus, and finally transported to the lysosomal system, which is the most well-developed method in current research.(5,41,42) In the other mechanism, lysosomal integral membrane protein 2 (LIMP-2) participates in the transport of glucocerebrosidase to lysosomes (Figure 3).(43â45) M6PR can effectively transport substrates to lysosomes and is widely expressed in tissues. Recently, it has been reported that receptors can be used to target lysosomes to successfully degrade extracellular proteins. Therefore, molecules that bind with high affinity for M6PR, LIMP-2, or other LTRs can be screened and linked to the target protein to achieve target protein degradation.
    There are two ways by which lysosomes clear protein aggregates, pathogens, and superfluous or damaged organelles in a selective manner. These two pathways are endocytosis and autophagy,(46,47) both of which lead to the degradation of substances from different sources in the cell.(5) Endocytosis is an important way to internalize cellular nutrients, access external information, and renew the plasma membrane.(48,49) This pathway begins at the plasma membrane and ends at the lysosome. Autophagy is a highly conserved cell degradation process that can be divided into three major types: macroautophagy,(50) microautophagy, and CMA. Macroautophagy is a process in which aggregated proteins are detected by autophagy receptors such as p62/SQSTM1 and are selectively blocked in autophagosomes and then fused with lysosomes through lysosomal hydrolases.(51â53) In macroautophagy, LC3, located on the autophagosomal membrane and in the autophagosome, can connect with a particular target protein and autophagosome. When we design a small-molecule drug targeting lysosomes, we can make full use of the bridge produced by LC3, which connects the target protein and the autophagosome. Microautophagy is a phagocytic process in which the lysosomal membrane directly engulfs intradermal cytoplasmic components. CMA is a unique highly selective autophagy mechanism that can only degrade certain specific proteins but not organelles. The most significant feature of CMA is the degradation of protein substrates with the KFERQ sequence.(54) To date, this specific CMA-targeting motif (CTM) has been found in all CMA substrates. Autophagy proceeds in all eukaryotic cells and is abnormally expressed in many human diseases, such as cancer, neurodegenerative diseases, and metabolic diseases.(55,56) Therefore, the use of autophagy to degrade certain target proteins may have potential applications to drug discovery.
    By studying how lysosomal biogenesis and lysosome-related components involved in this process mediate the different pathways of lysosome internalization and how the mechanisms of these pathways can be regulated, we can find new ways to target lysosomes. New techniques have been developed to target proteins and organelles for degradation through the lysosomal pathway. The development of lysosome-based degradation technique has good prospects for the treatment of diseases, especially neurodegenerative diseases.(57)

    Lysosome-Based Degradation Techniques

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Using the human lysosomal system to target protein degradation can lead to the degradation of various extracellular proteins, transmembrane proteins, protein aggregates, and organelles, thus greatly expanding the range of potential drug targets.(58â65) Therefore, increasing attention has been given to lysosome-based degradation technique. The lysosomal degradation pathway includes the endocytosis/lysosome pathway and autophagy pathway.(66,67) On the basis of endocytosis and different forms of autophagy, the techniques that target lysosomal degradation pathways can be divided into the following four types.

    Lysosome-Targeting Chimeras (LYTACs) for Drug Discovery

    The cation-independent mannose 6-phosphate receptor (CI-M6PR) is a representative receptor in the LTR family that can transport proteins to lysosomes.(44) CI-M6PR uses its constitutive circulation in the Golgi complex and endosomes and at the cell surface to induce the endocytosis and lysosomal degradation of N-glycan proteins capped with mannose 6-phosphate residues.(68) Banik et al. developed a lysosome-targeting chimera (LYTAC) by using CI-M6PR, which successfully led to the transport and degradation of target proteins (Figure 4).(58,69) These LYTACs are made by the fusion of antibodies to the target protein with chemically synthesized N-carboxyanhydride (NCA)-derived glycopolypeptides, which can target CI-M6PR.
    First, an NCA glycan peptide with an M6P branch and a specific antibody target protein binding to an LTR were designed and optimized. Different LYTACs were synthesized, in which the binding part of a targeted LTR consisted of NCA glycan peptides with different sizes and linkers, and the part with the targeting protein was NeutrAvidin-647 (NA-647) with an Alexa Fluor-647-labeled protein linked to biotin. Biotinylated LYTAC, created by optimizing NCA glycan peptides, can facilitate NA-647 uptake in various cell lines, such as breast cancer, cervical cancer, lymphoma, and leukemia cell lines. These outcomes show that the optimized LTR-targeting ligands can localize the target protein to the lysosome. Next, the effectiveness of the targeted protein was verified, and the first LYTAC molecule Ab-1 was synthesized by covalently coupling poly-serine-O-mannose-6-phosphonate (M6Pn) and polyclonal anti-mouse IgG. When Ab-1 was cultured with K562 cells and mouse IgG labeled with Alexa Fluor 488, the Alexa Fluor 488 fluorescence signal in the lysosome increased 40-fold compared with that in the control group. In addition, Ab-1 transported the mCherry protein and its antibody into the cell. Therefore, LYTAC can relocate the antibody from its normal site of immune function and achieve targeted extracellular protein degradation through the lysosome pathway.
    To determine whether LYTAC can induce degradation of the target protein via lysosomes, the LYTAC Ab-1 was found to transport ApoE4(70) (a protein involved in neurodegenerative diseases) into lysosomes for further degradation. In addition, when mouse anti-CD71 antibody and Ab-1 are incubated in the cells, CD71(71,72) is internalized and degraded by lysosomes. Eighty-one percent of CD71 was degraded after treatment with 50 nM anti-CD71 and Ab-1 in Jurkat cells for 24 h. Given these conclusions, LYTAC Ab-2 and LYTAC Ab-3 were designed, and these agents achieved the degradation of EGFR and PD-L1, respectively. Seventy-six percent of EGFR was degraded after treatment with 10 nM Ab-2 for 48 h in dCas9-KRAB HeLa cells. PD-L1 was downregulated with 73% after treatment with 25 nM atz-LYTAC for 48 h in HDLM-2 cells. Moreover, LYTAC Ab-2 constructed by covalently coupling poly(M6Pn) and the EGFR antibody cetuximab(73,74) can specifically degrade EGFR in a variety of cell lines, including HeLa cells and in breast cancer (BT474 and MDA-MB-361) and lung cancer (A549) cell lines, with no off-target effects. Notably, PD-L1 is the first type of transmembrane protein, with a size of 40 kDa, that helps cancer cells evade the immune system. When using anti-PD-L1-M6Pn LYTAC Ab-3 to treat PD-L1-positive MDA-MB-231 cells, a significant decrease in the level of PD-L1 on the cell surface was observed.
    CI-M6PR is one of many LTRs and is expressed in most tissues. The expression of some receptors in the LTR is tissue-specific. The design of molecules to target tissue-specific LTRs can lead to the degradation of target proteins in specific tissues and achieve precise treatment. Inspired by M6Pn-LYTAC, a research group developed an LYTAC targeting ASGPR, which is an LTR with tissue specificity. LYTAC is composed of an antibody that recognizes a target protein and glycoproteins bearing N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) that target ASGPR.(59,75,76) Since the expression of ASGPR is concentrated in the liver, GalNAc-LYTAC can achieve liver-specific target protein degradation.(77) Researchers cocultured liver cancer cells with other cells that do not express ASGPR and confirmed that GalNAc-LYTAC has cell specificity. GalNAc-LYTAC successfully induces the degradation of EGFR and HER2 in hepatocarcinoma cell lines, and this process depends on the lysosomal system of the cell and the internalization of ASGPR. Although a large number of target proteins are transported to lysosomes, lysosomal homeostasis is not destroyed, and other cell functions are not affected. In addition, because the expression of ASGPR on the surface of liver cells is higher than that of CI-M6PR, the degradation ability of GalNAc-LYTAC is stronger than that of M6Pn-LYTAC. In summary, the LYTAC technique targeting ASGPR is feasible, effective, and specific.
    In conclusion, the LYTAC technique can directly target extracellular and membrane-associated proteins for degradation via the lysosomal pathway. LYTAC is a good supplement to PROTACs, which use the ubiquitin degradation system and can only degrade intracellular proteins. Extracellular and membrane-associated proteins account for 40% of protein-coding genes(78) and are key factors in aging-related diseases, autoimmune diseases, and cancer; therefore, strategies for targeted degradation of these proteins have the potential to treat human diseases and improve human health. Although the aforementioned LYTAC makes full use of CI-M6PR, other recyclable receptors can also be used in principle. It is reasonable and necessary to find and study other recoverable ligands. In addition, the antibody has strong specificity and a low mistargeting rate, but this method also requires an antibody to maintain its characteristics when binding with recyclable ligands with effective targeting.

    Autophagy-Targeting Chimeras (AUTACs) for Drug Discovery

    Yoshimori et al. found that cells can activate autophagy to specifically remove pathogens when they are invaded by cytoplasmic group A streptococci.(79) Dr. Arimoto later discovered that S-guanylation is involved in the recognition events leading to the above-mentioned antibacterial autophagy.(80) The endogenous nucleotide 8-nitroguanosine 3â²,5â²-cyclic monophosphate (8-nitro-cGMP) is a signal for cells to recruit autophagosomes;(80â82) therefore, Takahashi et al. designed a small molecule named autophagy-targeting chimera (AUTAC) that recruits autophagosomes specifically based on endogenous cGMP modification (S-guanylation); this molecule consists of a tag for recruiting autophagosomes (guanine derivatives), a linker, and a ligand for targeting proteins or organelles for binding. Using this method, they successfully degraded cytoplasmic proteins and fragmented mitochondria (Figure 5).(60,83)
    The authors originally designed a cGMP-containing ligand probe to combine guanosine 3â²,5â²-cyclic monophosphate (cGMP) with a Halo tag. The application of this probe to EGFP indicated that it can induce EGFP S-guanylation and transport the protein to autophagosomes for degradation. However, due to the slow process of EGFP degradation by this probe, an analog probe, the p-fluorobenzylguanine ligand, was developed through optimization. The new probe has strong binding ability and undergoes rapid reaction.
    To verify the effectiveness of AUTACs in degrading proteins, researchers have used new probes to develop three small molecules, 1, 2, and 3, that can target degraded proteins. These researchers successfully designed and synthesized compound 1 to degrade methionine aminopeptidase 2 (MetAP-2).(84,85) As a bifunctional small molecule, compound 1 is mainly composed of three parts: p-fluorobenzylguanine (FBnG), a polyethylene glycol linker, and the hydrolysis product of fumagillol.(86â88) The degradation tag of 1 is p-fluorobenzylguanine, which can specifically recruit autophagosomes. The covalently bound part of 1 and MetAP-2 is a hydrolysate of fumagillol. The result demonstrated that more than 80% of extant MetAP-2 was successfully degraded in HeLa cells after treatment with 10 Î¼M AUTAC. When the lysosomal inhibitor bafilomycin A1 was added, the silencing of MetAP-2 was inhibited, which indicated that the degradation mechanism was accomplished by autophagy. FK506-binding protein(89,90) (FKBP12) participates in the release of intracellular Ca2+, which is related to immune suppression and nerve cell regeneration.(91) In HeLa cells, compound 2 at a concentration of 10 Î¼M successfully degraded FKBP12. In the design of compound 2, SLF (noncovalently targeting FKBP) was selected as the warhead for FKBP12, and it was connected to the p-fluorobenzylguanine ligand recruiting the autophagosome through a polyethylene glycol linker. Since the upregulation of bromodomain-containing protein 4(92) (BRD4) expression is closely related to the occurrence and development of lung cancer, breast cancer, acute myeloid lymphoma, liver cancer, and so on,(93â96) the authors synthesized compound 3, which was joined by the BRD4 inhibitors JQ1 and FBnG and named 3, to study its degradation effect. However, the results showed that the levels of BRD4 were only slightly reduced in A549 cells treated with 10 Î¼M compound 3.
    In addition, compound 4, which can deliver a guanine tag to the mitochondrial membrane, was prepared. It functions with a 2-phenylindole derivative as the binding agent for targeting mitochondria, and FBnG is connected to the other end by a polyethylene glycol linker unit. 2-Phenylindole 3-glyoxyamide is a ligand for translocator proteins on the outer mitochondrial membrane.(97,98) From the perspective of the autophagy substrate range, mitochondria were degraded after treatment with 10 Î¼M 4. Mitochondrial dysfunction is associated with many aging-related diseases; therefore, removing broken mitochondria may ameliorate these disease conditions. Targeted mitochondrial 4 (mito-AUTAC) treatment can significantly improve the mitochondrial activity of fibroblasts in Downâs syndrome. Compound 4 targeting mitochondria not only can accelerate the specific clearance of dysfunctional mitochondria in fibroblasts derived from patients but also can stimulate cells to assemble new mitochondria. At the same time, a cytoprotective effect against acute mitochondrial injury was also observed.
    These favorable results prove the feasibility of using AUTACs; therefore, AUTACs may have a wide range of applications in the discovery of autophagy-related drugs in the future. Despite these achievements, there are still some major challenges to be addressed. For example, the application of AUTACs to the removal of protein aggregates has not been tested. Although similar to PROTAC action, the AUTAC-mediated autophagy mechanism may be more complex than that of a PROTAC. Obviously, we need to have an in-depth understanding of the working mechanism of AUTACs. The modes of action of AUTACs differ from those of similar PROTACs that induce ubiquitin ligases to approach a substrate. In selective autophagy, substrate selectivity is usually achieved by ubiquitination of the substrate or direct recognition of the autophagy receptor. The mechanism of action of AUTAC degradation tags also needs to be clarified in detail. Furthermore, targeted protein degradation by PROTACs is completed within 1 h,(99) while targeted protein degradation by AUTACs takes several hours; therefore, the degradation rates of AUTACs need to be further optimized. Finally, AUTACs have been successfully applied to several cytoplasmic proteins, and the effect of nuclear proteins generally needs to be further studied and confirmed to better guide the wide application of AUTACs.

    Autophagosome-Tethering Compounds (ATTECs) for Drug Discovery

    To search for a small-molecule agent that degrades mutant huntingtin protein (mHTT) through autophagy, Lu and Feiâs group screened nearly 4000 small-molecule compounds through a new high-throughput compound screening platform based on small-molecule microarrays (SMMs) and oblique-incidence reflectivity difference (OI-RD) technology(100â105) to identify 5 (3-3-((3,5-dibromo-4-hydroxyphenyl)methylidene)-5-iodo-1H-indol-2-one) and 6 (N-(3-aminopropyl)-N-((1R)-1-(7-chloro-4-oxo-3-(phenylmethyl)-2-quinazolinyl)-2-methylpropyl)-4-methylbenzamide) (Figure 6).(61)5 and 6 selectively degraded mHTT but spared the wild-type HTT protein. These two compounds can bind both the LC3 protein and mutant huntingtin protein but not wild-type huntingtin protein. Through the detection of small-molecule compounds with similar features, the authors obtained two other ATTECs, 7 and 8, which can be referred to as small-molecule glue. ATTECs can specifically bind the key autophagy protein LC3 and the pathogenic protein without binding to the normal protein and specifically package the pathogenic material into the autophagosome for degradation. This research has finally achieved selective degradation of the pathogenic mutant huntingtin protein and can be applied to other polyQ diseases. This method is expected to provide new opportunities for the clinical treatment of Huntingtinâs disease.
    The mechanism of action of these small molecules was verified. Small molecules can indeed reduce the level of mHTT in fibroblasts from HD patients and neurons derived from induced pluripotent stem cells (iPS cells), as shown by the homogeneous time-resolved fluorescence (HTRF) assay,(106,107) but have no effect on the wild-type HTT protein in fibroblasts obtained from healthy people or patients with Parkinsonâs disease. The authors demonstrated that small molecules mediate mHTT degradation through autophagy by knocking out the key gene ATG5.(108) In addition, through the detection of the autophagy-selective substrate protein SQSTM1 (p62) and the control protein level, it was determined that small-molecule glue had no effect on the autophagy process. Phenotypic experiments were carried out in an HD transgenic fly model and a mouse model expressing mHTT. In transgenic flies expressing full-length HTT (Q128) driven by elav-GAL4, feeding the indicated compounds at 10 Î¼M for 6 days led to significantly reduced mHTT levels. The cortices from HdhQ7/Q140-knock-in mice intracerebroventricularly treated with one dose of 5, 7, or 8 (2 Î¼L at 25 Î¼M for each mouse) per day for 10 days showed significant degradation of mHTT. 5 and 8 can cross the bloodâbrain barrier and enter the brain. They can directly reduce mutant huntingtin protein levels in the cerebral cortex and striatum of mice with Huntingtinâs disease upon intraperitoneal injection at 0.5 mg kgâ1 without affecting the wild-type huntingtin protein levels in brain tissue. In addition, ATTECs can ameliorate HD-relevant phenotypes. ATTECs provide new strategies for the development of oral therapeutic drugs for Huntingtinâs disease.
    The internal mechanism of mHTTâLC3 linker compounds that can distinguish between mutant and wild-type HTT proteins was investigated. The mutant and wild-type HTT proteins are almost identical except for the difference in the length of an expanded polyglutamine (polyQ) tract. The results of this specificity study indicated that these linking compounds can recognize the conformation of the expanded polyQ stretch in the mHTT protein to distinguish between these two proteins. Consistent with this prediction, the researchers used the spinocerebellar ataxia type 3 cell line harboring the mutant ataxin-3 with an expanded polyQ region containing 74 glutamines to find that these linking compounds can effectively degrade the ataxin-3 protein mutants without affecting the concentration of wild-type ataxin-3.
    Lu et al.(61) demonstrated the idea of autophagic degradation of proteins (such as mHTT) by binding ATTEC compounds with LC3. The next key step in this new drug development strategy is to study in detail the interface between the compound and LC3 through medicinal chemistry and structural chemistry and to develop chemical molecules that match the interface without affecting the function. In addition, according to the existing common core structure, more effective small-molecule glues can be created to optimize the structure of the compound using strategies such as bioelectronics and skeleton transitions in pharmaceutical chemistry. Furthermore, in the absence of a known structure for these compounds, it is still possible to design compounds that specifically interact with mHTT and LC3 through coupled linkers identified by high-throughput screening of SMMs and OI-RD technology. However, there remain some questions requiring further study. It is not clear whether the ATTEC molecule damages normal brain proteins due to the increase in autophagy it induces or whether there are off-target effects, which may cause secondary damage to the nervous system.(109,110)

    Chaperone-Mediated Autophagy (CMA) Targets Protein Degradation through Lysosomes for Drug Discovery

    Molecular chaperone-mediated autophagy is the molecular chaperone HSC70 that recognizes a soluble cytoplasmic protein substrate with a KFERQ sequence (Figure 7). After the chaperoneâsubstrate complex binds to lysosome-associated membrane protein 2a on the lysosomal membrane, the substrate is transported into the lysosome via the HSC70 located in the lysosomal cavity, which is decomposed by a hydrolase and then reused by the cell.(111â113) Bauer et al. showed the expression of a 46 amino acid-peptide chain containing two different HSC70 binding motifs and two copies of the polyglutamine-binding peptide 1 sequence (QBP1),(114,115) which can recognize the expanded polyQ sequence in the mutant huntingtin protein without binding to the normal mutant huntingtin protein polyQ motif.(62) This peptide can specifically degrade mHTT with extended polyQ fragments via CMA. CMA promotes the specific degradation of HTT with expanded polyQ in Neuro2a cells expressing this construct. The results from experiments with R6/2 and HD190Q-EGFP mouse HD models clearly show that expressing a fusion molecule effectively reduces the expansion of HTT aggregation in vivo, and the reduction in HTT aggregation is accompanied by a decrease in the solubility level of polyQ. An in vivo study revealed that this molecule can ameliorate the pathology and phenotype of the HD model mice. To explain this effect, it is proposed that a peptide-like molecule with the HSC70-binding motif fused with a specific structural binding domain that can target the protein of interest (POI) may have the potential to treat diseases caused by a mutant protein.
    Wangâs group used CMA to degrade endogenous proteins to design a peptide system.(63) The peptide consists of three parts: a cell membrane penetrating domain (CMPD) that can be delivered across the bloodâbrain barrier and plasma membrane, a protein-binding domain (PBD) that specifically binds to the target protein, and CTM that can target lysosomes to hydrolyze proteins. When the targeting peptide is applied to the cell environment, it enters the cell through its CMPD and then specifically recognizes and forms a stable complex with its target protein through the interaction between PBD and CTM. Finally, the complex is translocated to the lysosome through the CMA pathway for rapid degradation. The team designed three of these targeted peptides that can degrade the scaffolding protein PSD-95, death-associated protein kinase 1 (DAPK1), and Î±-synuclein. Pretreatment of H2O2-induced neurons with DAPK1-targeting peptide (100 Î¼M) resulted in a 63.46% reduction in DAPK1 levels. In a well-characterized rat model of focal ischemia, treatment with DAPK1-targeting peptide at 10 mg kgâ1 reduced DAPK1 levels compared with the control. The results confirmed that the target peptide can knock out the protein of interest not only in primary neurons but also in rat brains and can cross the bloodâbrain barrier, as expected. In addition, Zhou et al. synthesized a peptide that can induce the degradation of cyclin-dependent kinase 5 (CDK5) through the specific binding of the partner-mediated autophagy-targeting motif (Tat-CDK5-CTM) with CDK5.(64) Tests confirmed that this peptide not only can prevent calcium overload and the death of cultured neurons but also can reduce infarct size and neuronal loss in mice with middle cerebral artery occlusion at 1 mg/kg and thus improve neurological function. This type of targeted peptide-directed lysosomal degradation provides a new method for regulating endogenous protein levels.
    Xuâs team discovered the PD-L1 lysosomal degradation pathway and its regulatory factor HIP1R.(65) HIP1R can directly interact with PD-L1 and deliver it for lysosomal degradation through the lysosomal targeted signaling pathway. They also found that the interaction between HIP1R and PD-L1 depends on the structural motif of PD-L1 and the signal peptide directed to the lysosome. Using this principle, this research team first designed peptides containing an epitope tag obtained for PD-L1 binding from HIP1R and a CMA sorting signal with the sequence KFERQQKILDQRFFE. The fusion peptides significantly reduced the level of PD-L1. Then, the researchers designed the PD-LYSO polypeptide. This synthetic peptide contains the region of HIP1R that binds to PD-L1 and the sequence that mediates the transport of PD-L1 to the lysosome and can target PD-L1 expressed by tumor cells and carry it to lysosomes for degradation.
    Peptide-targeting chimeras provide powerful tools for scientific research through the CMA degradation of proteins and offer new strategies for the development and treatment of diseases caused by misfolded proteins. However, there are still some shortcomings associated with this method: (i) designing these peptides requires a domain with a high affinity for the target protein, and (ii) the delivery and stability of these peptides as therapeutic agents remain problems to be resolved. Fortunately, researchers are constantly trying to improve this method and hope to treat various human diseases by this method in the future.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Currently, PROTACs that induce targeted protein degradation represent a brand-new technique that has attracted much attention. Compared with traditional drug inhibitors, PROTACs have potential advantages in terms of drug resistance, side effects, dosage, and the regulation of âundruggableâ targets. Lysosome-based degradation technique has more extensive substrates than PROTACs (Table 1) because it can degrade not only cytoplasmic proteins but also extracellular proteins, protein aggregates, organelles, and non-protein molecules, which are important functions not exhibited by proteasomes. Several technical platforms have been developed to degrade extracellular proteins, large proteins, and damaged organelles (Table 2). In addition, the role of a PROTAC depends on the specific E3 ligase subunit. Due to challenges with their expression, the application of PROTACs in specific cell types is limited. However, lysosomes exist in almost all animal cells (except mature red blood cells of mammals), and there are similar organelles in plant cells; therefore, in theory, lysosome-based degradation can be achieved in nearly all cell types.
    Table 1. Comparison of PROTACs and Lysosome-Based Degradation Technique
    degrader techniquedegradation applicationref
    PROTACIntracellular proteins(116)
    Pathogenic bacteria(117)
    Nuclear protein(118)
    Lysosome-based degradation techniqueIntracellular proteins(60)
    ExtracellularÂ substances(58)
    TransmembraneÂ proteins(63)
    Organelles(60)
    Protein aggregate(62)
    Table 2. Summary of the Advantages and Drawbacks of Various Degradation Techniques
    technologydegradation pathwayadvantagesdrawbacks
    PROTACsProteasome pathwayCatalytic; clear degradation mechanism; potent activity; spatiotemporal control.Depends on E3 ligase; unable to degrade extracellular proteins or organelles.
    LYTACsEndocytosis/lysosomeÂ pathwayDegradation of extracellular and transmembrane proteins; tissue specificity.High molecular weight; slow degradation rate.
    AUTACsMacroautophagy pathwayDegrades organelles and intracellular proteins.UnclearÂ mechanismsÂ ofÂ action.
    ATTECsMacroautophagy pathwayEasilyÂ crossesÂ theÂ bloodâbrain barrier.Lack of detailed interface between LC3 and the compound.
    TargetedÂ CMAÂ degradersCMA pathwayDegradation of transmembrane proteins and protein aggregates.Limited stability within the cell; poor cell permeability; weak activity.
    Lysosome-based degradation technique is still in an early stage, but some breakthroughs have been made. ATTECs, which are small-molecule binding compounds, can bind LC3 and pathogenic proteins (or other pathogenic substances) together and then encapsulate pathogenic proteins in autophagosomes for degradation by lysosomes. The small-molecule compound that can specifically reduce the pathogenic protein associated with Huntingtinâs disease reaches the nmol level in HD cells. In addition, in HD-knock-in mice, ATTECs at 0.5 mg kgâ1 reduced mHTT and reached the brain through the bloodâbrain barrier. These compounds have no effect on wild-type HTT. In addition, Lu et al. assessed protein levels in tissue samples. They found that only a small percentage of the protein levels changed in mice treated with the compound compared with the control animals. Currently, it is not clear whether the level changes of some proteins affect the function of normal proteins. The LYTAC technique platform has been used to successfully degrade disease-related proteins (including apolipoprotein E4, EGFR, CD71, and PD-L1) in vitro, which fully proves that the LYTAC technique platform can directly target extracellular and membrane-associated proteins for lysosomal degradation. The proteome-wide characterization of EGFR degradation specificity was assessed by quantitative mass spectrometry analysis of cells treated with LYTACs. Decreased levels of certain proteins may be associated with molecules regulated by EGFR. Targeted peptides were designed using specific recognition of molecular chaperones and autophagy substrate proteins to achieve selective degradation of specific proteins. These targeted peptide-directed lysosomes can rapidly and reversibly knock out endogenous proteins in situ. DAPK1-targeting peptide at 10 mg kgâ1 successfully reduced DAPK1 levels in vivo. AUTAC technique utilizing macroautophagy not only successfully degrades cytoplasmic proteins but also degrades damaged mitochondria selectively in cells, which provides new inspiration for the development of a system for degrading organelles. It is believed that targeting protein and organelle degradation through the lysosomal pathway is a promising therapeutic strategy.
    Obtaining the appropriate physicochemical properties and the absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion properties that are sufficient for oral administration and for the drugs to reach the central nervous system is extremely important. Currently, there are many methods to optimize PK, such as optimizing permeability, which can greatly improve bioavailability. Enhancing the solubility of the compound facilitates drug exposure in vivo and in vitro. However, bioavailability optimization of macromolecules such as AUTACs is still in its infancy. ATTECs are small molecules; therefore, PK can be optimized according to structureâactivity relationship studies. In addition, ATTECs and AUTACs may have catalytic activity and can be reused after the target protein is degraded by lysosomes, but this supposition requires further experimental validation. LYTACs and targeting peptides may be noncatalytic because their biomolecules may be degraded by lysosomes. In theory, the size of the AUTAC and targeting peptide affects the ability of the molecule to pass through the cell membrane. However, for LYTACs, molecular size is not a problem because they can cross the cell membrane by endocytosis.
    For the degradation of extracellular substances and plasma membrane proteins, lysosome-based degradation molecules can be designed by targeting LTRs that undergo endocytosis. For intracellular proteins and organelles, lysosome-based degradation molecules can be designed by targeting LTRs that undergo autophagy. Peptide molecules targeting CMA, AUTACs and ATTECs targeting autophagy, and LYTACs targeting LTRs have been developed. Lysosome-based degradation technique and PROTACs can enable the binding of two proteins to form a trimeric complex for which administration at high concentrations does not yield better results. The phenomenon associated with this characteristic is called the HOOK effect. This effect features PK/PD relationships and drug delivery patterns. The formation of all three components in a stable and long-lived trimer can be optimized to accelerate the degradation of the target and improve the efficacy of the degraders. Lysosome-based degradation molecules have a greater molecular weight than traditional small-molecule drugs, except for ATTECs, and may not effectively penetrate the biomembrane. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop degraders targeting lysosomes with lower molecular weight to take effect after passing through the biomembrane.
    Compared with PROTAC, the development of targeted lysosomal degradation technique is relatively lagging behind, but this degradation technique has been validated preliminarily at the cellular and animal levels, which greatly expands the range of targets for protein degradation agent technique. The critical challenge of the targeted lysosome-based degrader is how to rationally design and effectively promote the lysosome-based degrader into the clinic. First, the discovery of more ligands targeting lysosomes will promote development in the field of protein degradation. So far, only CI-M6PR and ASGPR have been developed for target protein degradation in LYTAC technique. The design of different small molecule ligands targeting lysosomal receptors can promote the diversification of LYTAC, and targeting the distribution of lysosomal receptors in different tissues can achieve the purpose of treating tissue-specific diseases. Targeting lysosomes through the autophagy pathway is also a strategy for developing targeted lysosome therapy. Autophagy can also transport intracellular waste products into lysosomes for degradation. Therefore, exploring new recruiting autophagy ligands will greatly expand the application of targeted lysosomal degradation. Whether the existing autophagy inhibitors or agonists can be used to design and recruit autophagy ligands needs further investigation. It is also possible to optimize the recruitment of autophagy ligands of AUTAC and ATEEC to make them universal targeted lysosomal ligands. For example, the specific mechanism of the interaction between ATTEC molecule and LC3 has not been clarified, therefore, the characterization of complex structure of ATTEC molecule and LC3 or the systematic structureâactivity relationship study will help in-depth understanding of the mode of action and clarify the mechanism and provide a basis for the rational design of high-affinity ligands targeting LC3. The design of peptides targeting lysosomes is relatively simple, so peptides coupled with small molecules can be considered to degrade target proteins. Structure-based drug design is helpful for the discovery and optimization of lead compounds for targeted lysosome-based degrader. High-throughput screening, especially DNA coding libraries (DELS), can rapidly screen a large number of molecules and is expected to obtain highly efficient ligands targeting lysosomes. These studies will facilitate the discovery of ligands with high affinity for lysosome and then greatly improve the degradation efficiency of lysosome degradation.
    Second, although some degradation agents have been studied in vivo in animals, the PK and PD of the drug need to be further studied. The ADME of degraders needs to be thoroughly investigated. Lysosome-based degraders are mainly large molecules, which may cause problems such as low permeability, poor tissue access, and reduced bioavailability; thus structural optimization is required and the PK and PD of the degradation agents need to be further studied. So far, LYTAC has no in vivo data disclosure. The PK properties of AUTAC molecules can be improved by chemical modification, such as ring formation, pharmacophore bioisostere replacement, and salt formation. ATTEC has relatively good ADME properties due to its smaller molecular weight; however, molecular glue currently lacks systematic design and discovery. In the future, we believe that scientists will develop more small molecular glue compounds based on experience and computer-aided drug design to improve their PK properties. On the other hand, there have been relatively few studies on peptide-targeted chimeras in recent years, which is mainly due to the rapid clearance of peptides from the kidneys and limited oral bioavailability. These inherent flaws can be overcome by chemical modification, physical technology, and nanomaterials, which have been proven to improve the ADME properties of polypeptides by improving cell permeability, enhancing proteolytic stability, and reducing renal clearance, thereby prolonging the half-life. This provides a potential for the druggability and clinical application of peptide-targeted chimeras.
    Lastly, drug-like factors of lysosome-based degraders need to be systematically investigated, including applicability, selectivity, and potential for undesired effects induced by off-target effects in vivo. Lysosome-based degraders should be tested in multiple cell types to determine their application and suitability. Additionally, it is necessary to study their biodistribution and biostability in vivo to avoid accumulation in healthy organs or tissues. The technique of degrading proteins of interest and organelles through the lysosomal pathway may also cause off-target effects and result in damage to normal proteins and organelles. Therefore, the safety and toxicity of degrading agents need to be fully explored including the dosage and the frequency to determine the potential for undesired effects and toxicity of the drug.
    Conclusively, the lysosome-based degradation technique has greatly expanded the âundruggableâ targets, especially in the treatment of neurodegenerative, metabolic, and aging diseases. It is believed that the development of a lysosome-based degradation techniques will lead to a wide range of therapeutic applications, providing new drug therapies for previously unconquerable diseases.

    1. 1
      Wang, F.; GÃ³mez-Sintes, R.; Boya, P. Lysosomal membrane permeabilization and cell death. Traffic 2018, 19, 918â 931, Â DOI: 10.1111/tra.12613
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      1
      Lysosomal membrane permeabilization and cell death
      Wang, Fengjuan; Gomez-Sintes, Raquel; Boya, Patricia
      Traffic (Oxford, United Kingdom) (2018), 19 (12), 918-931CODEN: TRAFFA; ISSN:1398-9219. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      A review. Lysosomes are membrane-enclosed organelles that mediate the intracellular degrdn. of macromols. They play an essential role in calcium regulation and have emerged as key signaling hubs in controlling the nutrient response. Maintaining lysosomal integrity and function is therefore crucial for cellular homeostasis. Different forms of stress can induce lysosomal membrane permeabilization (LMP), resulting in the translocation to the cytoplasm of intralysosomal components, such as cathepsins, inducing lysosomal-dependent cell death (LDCD). Here, we review recent advances that have furthered our understanding of the mol. mechanisms of LMP and the methods used to detect it. We discuss several endolysosomal damage-response mechanisms that mediate the repair or elimination of compromised lysosomes and summarize the role of LMP and cathepsins in LDCD and other cell death pathways. Finally, with the emergence of lysosomes as promising therapeutic targets for several human diseases, we review a variety of therapeutic strategies that seek to either destabilize lysosomes or to maintain, enhance or restore lysosomal function.

    2. 2
      Yim, W. W.-Y.; Mizushima, N. Lysosome biology in autophagy. Cell Discovery 2020, 6, 6, Â DOI: 10.1038/s41421-020-0141-7
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      2
      Lysosome biology in autophagy
      Yim, Willa Wen-You; Mizushima, Noboru
      Cell Discovery (2020), 6 (1), 6CODEN: CDEIBM; ISSN:2056-5968. (Nature Research)
      Abstr.: Autophagy is a major intracellular degrdn. system that derives its degradative abilities from the lysosome. The most well-studied form of autophagy is macroautophagy, which delivers cytoplasmic material to lysosomes via the double-membraned autophagosome. Other forms of autophagy, namely chaperone-mediated autophagy and microautophagy, occur directly on the lysosome. Besides providing the means for degrdn., lysosomes are also involved in autophagy regulation and can become substrates of autophagy when damaged. During autophagy, they exhibit notable changes, including increased acidification, enhanced enzymic activity, and perinuclear localization. Despite their importance to autophagy, details on autophagy-specific regulation of lysosomes remain relatively scarce. This review aims to provide a summary of current understanding on the behavior of lysosomes during autophagy and outline unexplored areas of autophagy-specific lysosome research.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXktlegtLs%253D&md5=bd5096a008d31a55449e6980b2bd9471

      Deus, C. M.; Yambire, K. F.; Oliveira, P. J.; Raimundo, N. Mitochondria-lysosome crosstalk: from physiology to neurodegeneration. Trends Mol. Med. 2020, 26, 71â 88, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.molmed.2019.10.009
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      3
      Mitochondria-Lysosome Crosstalk: From Physiology to Neurodegeneration
      Deus, Claudia M.; Yambire, King Faisal; Oliveira, Paulo J.; Raimundo, Nuno
      Trends in Molecular Medicine (2020), 26 (1), 71-88CODEN: TMMRCY; ISSN:1471-4914. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      A review. Cellular function requires coordination between different organelles and metabolic cues. Mitochondria and lysosomes are essential for cellular metab. as major contributors of chem. energy and building blocks. It is therefore pivotal for cellular function to coordinate the metabolic roles of mitochondria and lysosomes. However, these organelles do more than metab., given their function as fundamental signaling platforms in the cell that regulate many key processes such as autophagy, proliferation, and cell death. Mechanisms of crosstalk between mitochondria and lysosomes are discussed, both under physiol. conditions and in diseases that affect these organelles.

    5. 5
      Saftig, P.; Klumperman, J. Lysosome biogenesis and lysosomal membrane proteins: trafficking meets function. Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell Biol. 2009, 10, 623â 635, Â DOI: 10.1038/nrm2745
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      5
      Lysosome biogenesis and lysosomal membrane proteins: trafficking meets function
      Saftig, Paul; Klumperman, Judith
      Nature Reviews Molecular Cell Biology (2009), 10 (9), 623-635CODEN: NRMCBP; ISSN:1471-0072. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Lysosomes are the primary catabolic compartments of eukaryotic cells. They degrade extracellular material that has been internalized by endocytosis and intracellular components that have been sequestered by autophagy. In addn., specialized cells contain lysosome-related organelles that store and secrete proteins for cell-type-specific functions. The functioning of a healthy cell is dependent on the proper targeting of newly synthesized lysosomal proteins. Accumulating evidence suggests that there are multiple lysosomal delivery pathways that together allow the regulated and sequential deposition of lysosomal components. The importance of lysosomal trafficking pathways is emphasized by recent findings that reveal new roles for lysosomal membrane proteins in cellular physiol. and in an increasing no. of diseases that are characterized by defects in lysosome biogenesis.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXpsleqsrc%253D&md5=e45f191f35eba89f8936a7a9a9f76cdf

      Chieregatti, E.; Meldolesi, J. Regulated exocytosis: new organelles for non-secretory purposes. Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell Biol. 2005, 6, 181â 187, Â DOI: 10.1038/nrm1572
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      6
      Opinion: Regulated exocytosis: new organelles for non-secretory purposes
      Chieregatti, Evelina; Meldolesi, Jacopo
      Nature Reviews Molecular Cell Biology (2005), 6 (2), 181-187CODEN: NRMCBP; ISSN:1471-0072. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A discussion and review. Regulated exocytosis is a process in which the membranes of cytoplasmic organelles fuse with the plasma membrane in response to stimulation. In many cases (secretory exocytoses), the process functions to secrete specific products that are segregated in the organelle lumen (for example, neurotransmitters, hormones and enzymes) to the extracellular space. In other cases ('non-secretory exocytoses'), it functions to transfer the organelle membrane and its components to the cell surface. Here, the general properties of non-secretory exocytoses are discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXoslOnuw%253D%253D&md5=8d0d6f4b2f5d713ae30691a64de91794

      Zhao, Q.; Gao, S. M.; Wang, M. C. Molecular mechanisms of lysosome and nucleus communication. Trends Biochem. Sci. 2020, 45, 978â 991, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.tibs.2020.06.004
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      7
      Molecular Mechanisms of Lysosome and Nucleus Communication
      Zhao, Qian; Gao, Shihong Max; Wang, Meng C.
      Trends in Biochemical Sciences (2020), 45 (11), 978-991CODEN: TBSCDB; ISSN:0968-0004. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      A review. Lysosomes transcend the role of degrdn. stations, acting as key nodes for interorganelle crosstalk and signal transduction. Lysosomes communicate with the nucleus through phys. proximity and functional interaction. In response to external and internal stimuli, lysosomes actively adjust their distribution between peripheral and perinuclear regions and modulate lysosome-nucleus signaling pathways; in turn, the nucleus fine-tunes lysosomal biogenesis and functions through transcriptional controls. Changes in coordination between these two essential organelles are assocd. with metabolic disorders, neurodegenerative diseases, and aging. In this review, we address recent advances in lysosome-nucleus communication by multi-tiered regulatory mechanisms and discuss how these regulations couple metabolic inputs with organellar motility, cellular signaling, and transcriptional network.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXht1WlsLjJ&md5=efef671e93a93e45e44f00199ea06dcb
    8. 8
      Bonam, S. R.; Wang, F.; Muller, S. Lysosomes as a therapeutic target. Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2019, 18, 923â 948, Â DOI: 10.1038/s41573-019-0036-1
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      8
      Lysosomes as a therapeutic target
      Bonam, Srinivasa Reddy; Wang, Fengjuan; Muller, Sylviane
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2019), 18 (12), 923-948CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Research)
      Lysosomes are membrane-bound organelles with roles in processes involved in degrading and recycling cellular waste, cellular signalling and energy metab. Defects in genes encoding lysosomal proteins cause lysosomal storage disorders, in which enzyme replacement therapy has proved successful. Growing evidence also implicates roles for lysosomal dysfunction in more common diseases including inflammatory and autoimmune disorders, neurodegenerative diseases, cancer and metabolic disorders. With a focus on lysosomal dysfunction in autoimmune disorders and neurodegenerative diseases - including lupus, rheumatoid arthritis, multiple sclerosis, Alzheimer disease and Parkinson disease - this Review critically analyses progress and opportunities for therapeutically targeting lysosomal proteins and processes, particularly with small mols. and peptide drugs.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhs12gurrM&md5=705fc139e1d00bf2e1fb4267585ed9c7
    9. 9
      Tang, M.; Li, J.; Huang, W.; Su, H.; Liang, Q.; Tian, Z.; Horak, K. M.; Molkentin, J. D.; Wang, X. Proteasome functional insufficiency activates the calcineurin-NFAT pathway in cardiomyocytes and promotes maladaptive remodelling of stressed mouse hearts. Cardiovasc. Res. 2010, 88, 424â 433, Â DOI: 10.1093/cvr/cvq217
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      9
      Proteasome functional insufficiency activates the calcineurin-NFAT pathway in cardiomyocytes and promotes maladaptive remodelling of stressed mouse hearts
      Tang, Mingxin; Li, Jie; Huang, Wei; Su, Huabo; Liang, Qiangrong; Tian, Zongwen; Horak, Kathleen M.; Molkentin, Jeffery D.; Wang, Xuejun
      Cardiovascular Research (2010), 88 (3), 424-433CODEN: CVREAU; ISSN:0008-6363. (Oxford University Press)
      Aims Proteasome functional insufficiency (PFI) may play an important role in the progression of congestive heart failure but the underlying mol. mechanism is poorly understood. Calcineurin and nuclear factor of activated T-cells (NFAT) are degraded by the proteasome, and the calcineurin-NFAT pathway mediates cardiac remodelling. The present study examd. the hypothesis that PFI activates the calcineurin-NFAT pathway and promotes maladaptive remodelling of the heart. Methods and results Using a reporter gene assay, we found that pharmacol. inhibition of 20S proteasomes stimulated NFAT transactivation in both mouse hearts and cultured adult mouse cardiomyocytes. Proteasome inhibition stimulated NFAT nuclear translocation in a calcineurin-dependent manner and led to a maladaptive cell shape change in cultured neonatal rat ventricular myocytes. Proteasome inhibition facilitated left ventricular dilatation and functional decompensation and increased fatality in mice with aortic constriction while causing cardiac hypertrophy in the sham surgery group. It was further revealed that both calcineurin protein levels and NFAT transactivation were markedly increased in the mouse hearts with desmin-related cardiomyopathy and severe PFI. Expression of an aggregation-prone mutant desmin also directly increased calcineurin protein levels in cultured cardiomyocytes. Conclusions The calcineurin-NFAT pathway in the heart can be activated by proteasome inhibition and is activated in the heart of a mouse model of desmin-related cardiomyopathy that is characterized by severe PFI. The interplay between PFI and the calcineurin-NFAT pathway may contribute to the pathol. remodelling of cardiomyocytes characteristic of congestive heart failure.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhsVSltLvI&md5=fe920fc0f006dd0c98fa7308063954b7
    10. 10
      Pan, B.; Li, J.; Parajuli, N.; Tian, Z.; Wu, P.; Lewno, M. T.; Zou, J.; Wang, W.; Bedford, L.; Mayer, R. J.; Fang, J.; Liu, J.; Cui, T.; Su, H.; Wang, X. The calcineurin-TFEB-p62 pathway mediates the activation of cardiac macroautophagy by proteasomal malfunction. Circ. Res. 2020, 127, 502â 518, Â DOI: 10.1161/CIRCRESAHA.119.316007
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      10
      The Calcineurin-TFEB-p62 Pathway Mediates the Activation of Cardiac Macroautophagy by Proteasomal Malfunction
      Pan, Bo; Li, Jie; Parajuli, Nirmal; Tian, Zongwen; Wu, Penglong; Lewno, Megan T.; Zou, Jianqiu; Wang, Wenjuan; Bedford, Lynn; Mayer, R. John; Fang, Jing; Liu, Jinbao; Cui, Taixing; Su, Huabo; Wang, Xuejun
      Circulation Research (2020), 127 (4), 502-518CODEN: CIRUAL; ISSN:0009-7330. (Lippincott Williams & Wilkins)
      Objective: Systemic proteasome inhibition (PSMI) was shown to increase p62/SQSTM1 expression and induce myocardial macroautophagy. Methods and results: Myocardial macroautophagy, TFEB (transcription factor EB) expression and activity, and p62 expression were markedly increased in mice with either cardiomyocyte-restricted ablation of Psmc1 (an essential proteasome subunit gene) or pharmacol. PSMI. In cultured cardiomyocytes, PSMI-induced increases in TFEB activation and p62 expression were blunted by pharmacol. and genetic calcineurin inhibition and by siRNA-mediated Molcn1 silencing. Bortezomib-induced left ventricular wall thickening and diastolic malfunction was exacerbated by p62 deficiency. In cultured cardiomyocytes from wild type mice but not p62-KO mice, PSMI induced increases in LC3-II flux and the lysosomal removal of ubiquitinated proteins. Myocardial TFEB activation by PSMI as reflected by TFEB nuclear localization and target gene expression was strikingly less in p62-KO mice compared with wild type mice. Conclusions: (1) The activation of cardiac macroautophagy by proteasomal malfunction is mediated by the Mocln1-calcineurin-TFEB-p62 pathway; (2) p62 unexpectedly exerts a feed-forward effect on TFEB activation by proteasome malfunction; and (3) targeting the Mcoln1-calcineurin-TFEB-p62 pathway provide new means to intervene cardiac autophagic-lysosomal pathway activation during proteasome malfunction.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      Ding, Y.; Fei, Y.; Lu, B. Emerging new concepts of degrader technologies. Trends Pharmacol. Sci. 2020, 41, 464â 474, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.tips.2020.04.005
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      11
      Emerging New Concepts of Degrader Technologies
      Ding, Yu; Fei, Yiyan; Lu, Boxun
      Trends in Pharmacological Sciences (2020), 41 (7), 464-474CODEN: TPHSDY; ISSN:0165-6147. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      A review. Traditional drug discovery focuses on identifying direct inhibitors of target proteins. This typically relies on a measurable biochem. readout and accessible binding sites whose occupancy influences the function of the target protein. These requirements preclude many disease-causing proteins from being 'druggable' targets, and these proteins are categorized as 'undruggable'. The proteolysis-targeting chimera (PROTAC) technol. provides powerful tools to degrade these undruggable targets and has become a promising approach for drug discovery. However, the PROTAC technol. has some limitations, and emerging new degrader technologies may greatly broaden the spectrum of targets that could be selectively degraded by harnessing a second major degrdn. pathway in cells. We review key emerging technologies that exploit the lysosomal degrdn. pathway and discuss their potential applications and limitations.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXovVChurk%253D&md5=8614b50f72ee30c80d965db683cfd194

      Dybas, J. M.; Herrmann, C.; Weitzman, M. D. Ubiquitination at the interface of tumor viruses and DNA damage responses. Curr. Opin. Virol. 2018, 32, 40â 47, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.coviro.2018.08.017
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      12
      Ubiquitination at the interface of tumor viruses and DNA damage responses
      Dybas, Joseph M.; Herrmann, Christin; Weitzman, Matthew D.
      Current Opinion in Virology (2018), 32 (), 40-47CODEN: COVUAF; ISSN:1879-6257. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. Viruses exploit cellular ubiquitination machinery to shape the host proteome and promote productive infection. Among the cellular processes influenced by viral manipulation of ubiquitination is the DNA damage response (DDR), a network of cellular signaling pathways that sense and respond to genomic damage. This host-pathogen interaction is particularly important during virus replication and transformation by DNA tumor viruses. Manipulating DDR pathways can promote virus replication but also impacts host genomic instability, potentially leading to cellular transformation and tumor formation. We review ways in which viruses are known to hijack the cellular ubiquitin system to reshape host DDR pathways.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhs12nt7jO&md5=a09b76664af51715fc0d65e661c5189d

      Mahon, C.; Krogan, N. J.; Craik, C. S.; Pick, E. Cullin E3 ligases and their rewiring by viral factors. Biomolecules 2014, 4, 897â 930, Â DOI: 10.3390/biom4040897
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      13
      Cullin E3 ligases and their rewiring by viral factors
      Mahon, Cathal; Krogan, Nevan J.; Craik, Charles S.; Pick, Elah
      Biomolecules (2014), 4 (4), 897-930, 34 pp.CODEN: BIOMHC; ISSN:2218-273X. (MDPI AG)
      A review. The ability of viruses to subvert host pathways is central in disease pathogenesis. Over the past decade, a crit. role for the Ubiquitin Proteasome System (UPS) in counteracting host immune factors during viral infection has emerged. This counteraction is commonly achieved by the expression of viral proteins capable of sequestering host ubiquitin E3 ligases and their regulators. In particular, many viruses hijack members of the Cullin-RING E3 Ligase (CRL) family. Viruses interact in many ways with CRLs in order to impact their ligase activity; one key recurring interaction involves re-directing CRL complexes to degrade host targets that are otherwise not degraded within host cells. Removal of host immune factors by this mechanism creates a more amenable cellular environment for viral propagation. To date, a small no. of target host factors have been identified, many of which are degraded via a CRL-proteasome pathway. Substantial effort within the field is ongoing to uncover the identities of further host proteins targeted in this fashion and the underlying mechanisms driving their turnover by the UPS. Elucidation of these targets and mechanisms will provide appealing anti-viral therapeutic opportunities. This review is focused on the many methods used by viruses to perturb host CRLs, focusing on substrate sequestration and viral regulation of E3 activity.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhvV2isrzI&md5=dec804942b4aec1f00a77a3570c95b47

      Dharmasiri, N.; Dharmasiri, S.; Estelle, M. The F-box protein TIR1 is an auxin receptor. Nature 2005, 435, 441â 445, Â DOI: 10.1038/nature03543
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      14
      The F-box protein TIR1 is an auxin receptor
      Dharmasiri, Nihal; Dharmasiri, Sunethra; Estelle, Mark
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2005), 435 (7041), 441-445CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      The plant hormone auxin regulates diverse aspects of plant growth and development. Recent studies indicate that auxin acts by promoting the degrdn. of the Aux/IAA transcriptional repressors through the action of the ubiquitin protein ligase SCFTIR1. The nature of the signalling cascade that leads to this effect is not known. However, recent studies indicate that the auxin receptor and other signalling components involved in this response are sol. factors. Using an in vitro pull-down assay, we demonstrate that the interaction between transport inhibitor response 1 (TIR1) and Aux/IAA proteins does not require stable modification of either protein. Instead auxin promotes the Aux/IAA-SCFTIR1 interaction by binding directly to SCFTIR1. We further show that the loss of TIR1 and three related F-box proteins eliminates saturable auxin binding in plant exts. Finally, TIR1 synthesized in insect cells binds Aux/IAA proteins in an auxin-dependent manner. Together, these results indicate that TIR1 is an auxin receptor that mediates Aux/IAA degrdn. and auxin-regulated transcription.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar

      Proteolysis-Targeting Chimeras as Therapeutics and Tools for Biological Discovery
      Burslem, George M.; Crews, Craig M.
      Cell (Cambridge, MA, United States) (2020), 181 (1), 102-114CODEN: CELLB5; ISSN:0092-8674. (Cell Press)
      A review. New biol. tools provide new techniques to probe fundamental biol. processes. Here we describe the burgeoning field of proteolysis-targeting chimeras (PROTACs), which are capable of modulating protein concns. at a post-translational level by co-opting the ubiquitin-proteasome system. We describe the PROTAC technol. and its application to drug discovery and provide examples where PROTACs have enabled novel biol. insights. Furthermore, we provide a workflow for PROTAC development and use and discuss the benefits and issues assocd. with PROTACs. Finally, we compare PROTAC-mediated protein-level modulation with other technologies, such as RNAi and genome editing.

      Lai, A. C.; Crews, C. M. Induced protein degradation: an emerging drug discovery paradigm. Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2017, 16, 101â 114, Â DOI: 10.1038/nrd.2016.211
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      16
      Induced protein degradation: an emerging drug discovery paradigm
      Lai, Ashton C.; Crews, Craig M.
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2017), 16 (2), 101-114CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Small-mol. drug discovery has traditionally focused on occupancy of a binding site that directly affects protein function, and this approach typically precludes targeting proteins that lack such amenable sites. Furthermore, high systemic drug exposures may be needed to maintain sufficient target inhibition in vivo, increasing the risk of undesirable off-target effects. Induced protein degrdn. is an alternative approach that is event-driven: upon drug binding, the target protein is tagged for elimination. Emerging technologies based on proteolysis-targeting chimaeras (PROTACs) that exploit cellular quality control machinery to selectively degrade target proteins are attracting considerable attention in the pharmaceutical industry owing to the advantages they could offer over traditional small-mol. strategies. These advantages include the potential to reduce systemic drug exposure, the ability to counteract increased target protein expression that often accompanies inhibition of protein function and the potential ability to target proteins that are not currently therapeutically tractable, such as transcription factors, scaffolding and regulatory proteins.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhvFCit7rP&md5=a01ff43e9b696fe4dc03f0815158a98f
    17. 17
      Schapira, M.; Calabrese, M. F.; Bullock, A. N.; Crews, C. M. Targeted protein degradation: expanding the toolbox. Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2019, 18, 949â 963, Â DOI: 10.1038/s41573-019-0047-y
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      17
      Targeted protein degradation: expanding the toolbox
      Schapira, Matthieu; Calabrese, Matthew F.; Bullock, Alex N.; Crews, Craig M.
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2019), 18 (12), 949-963CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Research)
      A review. Proteolysis-targeting chimeras (PROTACs) and related mols. that induce targeted protein degrdn. by the ubiquitin-proteasome system represent a new therapeutic modality and are the focus of great interest, owing to potential advantages over traditional occupancy-based inhibitors with respect to dosing, side effects, drug resistance and modulating 'undruggable' targets. However, the technol. is still maturing, and the design elements for successful PROTAC-based drugs are currently being elucidated. Importantly, fewer than 10 of the more than 600 E3 ubiquitin ligases have so far been exploited for targeted protein degrdn., and expansion of knowledge in this area is a key opportunity. Here, we briefly discuss lessons learned about targeted protein degrdn. in chem. biol. and drug discovery and systematically review the expression profile, domain architecture and chem. tractability of human E3 ligases that could expand the toolbox for PROTAC discovery.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      The current state and future directions of RNAi-based therapeutics
      Setten, Ryan L.; Rossi, John J.; Han, Si-ping
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2019), 18 (6), 421-446CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Research)
      A review. The RNA interference (RNAi) pathway regulates mRNA stability and translation in nearly all human cells. Small double-stranded RNA mols. can efficiently trigger RNAi silencing of specific genes, but their therapeutic use has faced numerous challenges involving safety and potency. However, August 2018 marked a new era for the field, with the US Food and Drug Administration approving ONPATTRO, the first RNAi-based drug. In this Review, we discuss key advances in the design and development of RNAi drugs leading up to this landmark achievement, the state of the current clin. pipeline and prospects for future advances, including novel RNAi pathway agents utilizing mechanisms beyond post-translational RNAi silencing.

      Mutant NPM1 Maintains the Leukemic State through HOX Expression
      Brunetti, Lorenzo; Gundry, Michael C.; Sorcini, Daniele; Guzman, Anna G.; Huang, Yung-Hsin; Ramabadran, Raghav; Gionfriddo, Ilaria; Mezzasoma, Federica; Milano, Francesca; Nabet, Behnam; Buckley, Dennis L.; Kornblau, Steven M.; Lin, Charles Y.; Sportoletti, Paolo; Martelli, Maria Paola; Falini, Brunangelo; Goodell, Margaret A.
      Cancer Cell (2018), 34 (3), 499-512.e9CODEN: CCAECI; ISSN:1535-6108. (Elsevier Inc.)
      NPM1 is the most frequently mutated gene in cytogenetically normal acute myeloid leukemia (AML). In AML cells, NPM1 mutations result in abnormal cytoplasmic localization of the mutant protein (NPM1c); however, it is unknown whether NPM1c is required to maintain the leukemic state. Here, we show that loss of NPM1c from the cytoplasm, either through nuclear relocalization or targeted degrdn., results in immediate downregulation of homeobox (HOX) genes followed by differentiation. Finally, we show that XPO1 inhibition relocalizes NPM1c to the nucleus, promotes differentiation of AML cells, and prolongs survival of Npm1-mutated leukemic mice. We describe an exquisite dependency of NPM1-mutant AML cells on NPM1c, providing the rationale for the use of nuclear export inhibitors in AML with mutated NPM1.

      Clift, D.; Mcewan, W. A.; Labzin, L. I.; Konieczny, V.; Mogessie, B.; James, L. C.; Schuh, M. J. C. A Method for the acute and rapid degradation of endogenous proteins. Cell 2017, 171, 1692â 1706, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.033
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      20
      A Method for the Acute and Rapid Degradation of Endogenous Proteins
      Clift, Dean; McEwan, William A.; Labzin, Larisa I.; Konieczny, Vera; Mogessie, Binyam; James, Leo C.; Schuh, Melina
      Cell (Cambridge, MA, United States) (2017), 171 (7), 1692-1706.e18CODEN: CELLB5; ISSN:0092-8674. (Cell Press)
      Methods for the targeted disruption of protein function have revolutionized science and greatly expedited the systematic characterization of genes. Two main approaches are currently used to disrupt protein function: DNA knockout and RNA interference, which act at the genome and mRNA level, resp. A method that directly alters endogenous protein levels is currently not available. Here, the authors present Trim-Away, a technique to degrade endogenous proteins acutely in mammalian cells without prior modification of the genome or mRNA. Trim-Away harnesses the cellular protein degrdn. machinery to remove unmodified native proteins within minutes of application. This rapidity minimizes the risk that phenotypes are compensated and that secondary, non-specific defects accumulate over time. Because Trim-Away uses antibodies, it can be applied to a wide range of target proteins using off-the-shelf reagents. Trim-Away allows the study of protein function in diverse cell types, including non-dividing primary cells where genome- and RNA-targeting methods are limited.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhvValur%252FE&md5=255d6ce0a6a66720f57e4c3d3071a3b4

      Locus-specific knock-in of a degradable tag for target validation studies.
      Brand, Matthias; Winter, Georg E.
      Methods in Molecular Biology (New York, NY, United States) (2019), 1953 (Target Identification and Validation in Drug Discovery), 105-119CODEN: MMBIED; ISSN:1940-6029. (Springer)
      Small mol.-induced targeted protein degrdn. is a powerful approach for drug target validation given its selectivity, high kinetic resoln., dose dependency, and reversibility. Out of the several methods that have been reported so far, the 12 kDa degrdn. tag (dTAG) system has the advantage of hijacking a degrdn. machinery that is ubiquitously expressed in all human tissues. Therefore it is independent of expressing addnl., exogenous factors and addnl. permits target validation in vivo. Here, we describe the protocol for generation and validation of clones harboring knock-in of a selectable dTAG cassette at the endogenous locus of proteins of interest using the near-haploid cell line KBM7.
